docs.lead_paragraph: Health care reform -- which is crucial for millions of Americans -- hangs in the balance. Progressives are desperately in need of leadership; more specifically, House Democrats need to be told to pass the Senate bill, which isn't what they wanted but is vastly better than nothing. And what we get from the great progressive hope, the man who was offering hope and change, is this:

headline.main: He Wasn't The One We've Been Waiting For

docs.abstract: Right now, Barack Obama seems to be confirming all the skeptics' doubts.
docs.snippet: Right now, Barack Obama seems to be confirming all the skeptics' doubts.

docs.lead_paragraph: The polls had barely opened in Massachusetts on election day, a winter dawn that showed Democrats really were going to lose the seat of the lion Teddy Kennedy, when the stocks of big health care companies started to surge.
docs.abstract: Following their Massachusetts debacle, will Democrats learn something from the Red Sox - or "just lay there and bleed," as the old t-shirt had it?
docs.snippet: Following their Massachusetts debacle, will Democrats learn something from the Red Sox - or "just lay there and bleed," as the old t-shirt had it?

docs.lead_paragraph: Last week, the Obama administration struck a deal with labor leaders to temporarily exempt union members from paying the excise tax on more generous health insurance plans. Why was this such a big deal?
docs.abstract: How much union and nonunion workers pay for employer-sponsored health insurance premiums.
docs.snippet: How much union and nonunion workers pay for employer-sponsored health insurance premiums.

docs.lead_paragraph: With Democrats reeling from the Republican victory in the Massachusetts special Senate election, President Obama on Wednesday signaled that he might be willing to set aside his goal of achieving near-universal health coverage for all Americans in favor of a stripped-down measure with bipartisan support.

headline.main: Health Care Bill May Be Scaled Back

docs.abstract: President Obama on Wednesday signaled that he might be willing to set aside his goal of achieving near-universal health coverage for all Americans in favor of a stripped-down measure with bipartisan support.
docs.snippet: President Obama on Wednesday signaled that he might be willing to set aside his goal of achieving near-universal health coverage for all Americans in favor of a stripped-down measure with bipartisan support.

byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama said today that Democratic leaders in Congress should not try to "jam" the health care bill through in the coming days, saying that lawmakers should wait to move forward on the legislation until Republican Senator-elect Scott Brown of Massachusetts is seated.

headline.main: Obama: Seat Brown Before Moving Ahead on Health Care Bill

docs.abstract: The president argues that the voters' discontent that swept Scott Brown into office is the same sentiment that elected him one year ago.
docs.snippet: The president argues that the voters' discontent that swept Scott Brown into office is the same sentiment that elected him one year ago.

docs.lead_paragraph: ALBANY -- Fresh off the upset victory of Republican contender Scott Brown in the Massachusetts' Senate race, Bruce A. Blakeman, a Republican lawyer from New York City, arrived here on Wednesday to discuss his plans to run against Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand, the Democratic incumbent, this fall.

headline.main: A Republican Steps Up to Senate Battle

docs.abstract: A Republican from Long Island makes his case for running against Kirsten E. Gillibrand, a Democrat and the incumbent senator from New York.
docs.snippet: A Republican from Long Island makes his case for running against Kirsten E. Gillibrand, a Democrat and the incumbent senator from New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: David, sorry I was slow reaching out to you Tuesday night. It's very hard to write when one is crouched in a fetal position under the bed. Maybe if I remove the pillow from over my head ...

headline.main: What the Results in Massachusetts Mean

docs.abstract: Gail Collins wants the health care bill passed now; David Brooks thinks it's time for Democrats to show some humility.
docs.snippet: Gail Collins wants the health care bill passed now; David Brooks thinks it's time for Democrats to show some humility.

byline.original: By DAVID BROOKS AND GAIL COLLINS

docs.lead_paragraph: There's a scenario, believe it or not, in which Scott Brown's stunning win last night could actually end up forestalling a massive G.O.P. sweep next November. It involves Barack Obama swallowing his pride, behaving like a President who's just been thumped, and making a very public show of internalizing the lessons of last night in Massachusetts. And it involves dismissing, immediately and with prejudice, the liberal fantasy that Rahm Emanuel should spend the next few weeks "knocking heads together" in the House, in the hopes of pushing the Senate bill through Congress.
docs.abstract: How the White House should react to Scott Brown's win.
docs.snippet: How the White House should react to Scott Brown's win.

docs.lead_paragraph: In an interview with NBC's "Today" show Wednesday morning, Senator-elect Scott Brown was asked if his victory was a referendum on President Obama.
docs.abstract: The senator-elect from Massachusetts says his victory was bigger than a referendum on President Obama's agenda.
docs.snippet: The senator-elect from Massachusetts says his victory was bigger than a referendum on President Obama's agenda.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator-elect Scott Brown, Republican of Massachusetts, said in his victory speech that he is anxious to get to Washington and start his new job. But Mr. Brown, who owes his victory to independent voters, will quickly find himself at the center of a partisan typhoon over the fate of the major health care legislation.

headline.main: Supported by Brown, Massachusetts Reform Was a Model for Democrats in Washington

docs.abstract: Senator-elect Scott Brown supported the health care overhaul in Massachusetts, which in many ways resembles the Democratic health care legislation.
docs.snippet: Senator-elect Scott Brown supported the health care overhaul in Massachusetts, which in many ways resembles the Democratic health care legislation.
